So. Are we not watching not only athletes performing but the competing pharmacologies, surgeries, and healing techniques on which their performances depend? Since, obviously there are not yet any longitudinal studies on the effects the new treatments will have on athletes, they are at risk as they submit to procedures designed to enhance their performance and extend playing careers. But the highly  advanced and very expensive technologies involved that intervene on the playing fields and courts, I submit, diminish the very concept of sporting competition. Thus, to many of us, the record book reads, Bary Bonds + Big Pharm = Home Run King. Where are the heroes of yesteryear, depending on their own training, stamina, and skill?

The framework for debate here has been set so narrowly and pitched so one-sidedly that you don't add anything new to the debate that hasn't already been said by the NY Post. Once again it's a pitched battle of idealistic young teachers versus the old entrenched ones, with the all-powerful Union twisting the arm of the plucky mayor and his brave "reformers." Of course today to be an idealist means to spend your Saturdays helping a kid cram to pass a test because, like Bloomberg believes wholeheartedly, the things that can be measured are the only things that count. It would be refreshing for the Times to add something new to the debate: Consider investigating if Charter Schools are a wise use of our public education dollars. Investigate how the Department of Education guidelines for Special Education are effectively cutting services for special needs children while saying those services are being provided. Audit the financial decision-making of several schools (principals have 100% control of their budgets, and some principals have only been on the job a year or two) and see where the money actually goes. And finally, why not interview an older teacher, who yes, is getting paid some $60 or $70 thousand dollars a year - still less than a sanitation worker - and ask them what they do for the kids. I think you'll find that there are idealists across the spectrum, old and young, and that those who aren't working could be gotten out if the administrators were doing their jobs.

I am in my 4th year of teaching. I am not as worried about losing my job now as I am about what would happen if I were to remain a teacher for 25 years only to be fired because a principal could hire two new teachers for the same price. It's unfair that older teachers are not just unappreciated, but are being slandered, with no one coming to their defense and everyone rallying around the 25 year olds who look better on camera.

Banks have been using usury interest and micro-fees to enhance their gilded wastebaskets for a while now while advertising fewer fees or no fees for their wealthier clients. These micro-fees and usury interest payments fall heavily onto people who already have little or no access to capital.

When chastened even lightly the banks cry foul because the consumers can adopt some flimsy protection from overdrafts, etc. What is not written about is that often those overdraft protections come with credit checks. Not to mention that when one is poor and without access to capital in this society, if you need to feed the kids for two days before payday and the rest of your family suffers similar hardships, the only option is to overdraft a bank account or walk down to the local homeless shelter. That is a bit of a difficult journey for Americans who are not used to even seeing breadlines let alone standing in one with their kids. The overdraft fee or other micro-fee looks like a pretty good value under these conditions. All for which the bank is generally rewarded a handsome 2000 percent usury fee.

In America one has to pay to be poor. It's been that way for quite a while.

The benefits card in my state, which mandates transactions through Wells Fargo/Wachovia, also mandates fees for more than one withdrawal per week, balance inquiries conducted at at ATM, and denial of transactions for inadvertently entering an incorrect PIN.
Another issue with these cards is that, as with most ATM cash transactions, withdrawals are limited to multiples of $20. That means a small balance remains typically remains locked in the account even after benefits are no longer being received, unless you have access to a computer and are able to apply the balance to an online bill. This cannot be fully avoided even if you have access to a direct deposit checking account, because the first one or two receipts typically cannot be set up to flow to the bank of your choice.
Incidentally, these cards -- and the attendant junk fees -- are also now commonly used for payrolls by temp and hourly employment agencies. Just another way to gouge the working poor and financially unsophisticated.

If the practice is "inconsistent with federal law", why isn't the Department of Labor cracking down on these banks?  I guess "inconsistent" is not quite the same as a violation of law or regulation, but certainly these practices ought to be illegal.

I did what Gary did for the same reason. After I ran out of benefits in August, I wanted to officially close this account because, buried in the fine print, I found an "Inactive Account" fee of "$1.50 per month after 12 months of inactivity." The toll-free Customer Service Help Line had only automated options, none of which served my need. In that same fine print, I found a post office box address. After about three weeks my letter was returned as "unable to forward." Now I'm waiting to see what will happen next August.

Maybe the rules have changed in Texas. I had the choice of direct deposit or debit card for my unemployment benefits and had the latest amount deposited less than 2 weeks ago. Having worked for the company that "invented" these debit cards for payroll purposes, I am very familiar with the abusive charges and fees to the cardholder. Everyone but the cardholder gets a cut of the fees, thus the push for their use. Employment agencies are pushing these cards as well. Consumer advocates need to roll out educational campaigns on these cards, as well as the availability/benefits of free basic checking accounts from many banks, so those that are least able to afford these abuses won't fall prey to them.

This sounds like you would be taking a huge risk using this service because you would be alerting credit companies to the fact that you think you have a problem with your financial situation. Since you have to "enter information on (your) financial situation by answering questions about whether (you) own a home, what (you) think (your) credit score is and (your) ZIP code," it wouldn't take a data aggregation business any time at all to figure out who you are. (Not to mention any information that you might reveal via your phone or web browser). Which I'm sure is the point of this service in the first place.

No doubt credit companies -- and banking and insurance companies, too -- would pay to have this info. And no doubt they would use this to raise your rates or deny you insurance.

Why do you keep recommending these web sites that obviously are using our data against us to make a profit without explaining the HUGE pitfalls to revealing such data online?

My initial impression of the visual aspects of the tool include: welcoming, friendly and calming. And I too appreciate the reassuring Debt Coach character as I am walked through the Debt Coach tool. As I make my way through each step, there is a “Debt Assessment” graph that gets updated as the tool gathers more information about my finances. I chose to manually enter each of my debts (instead of having a credit report pulled). The tool has the ability to auto fill many of the creditor names. Not only do the debt option results show the best fit for my situation, it also shows which options wouldn’t work for me (such as credit counseling or debt relief). As a matter of fact, it validated my current strategy to pay down my debts as the best one (Optimized Payments).

Everett Dirksen: “With respect to authorization bills, I do not want the Congress or the country to commit fiscal suicide on the installment plan.”
Bob Dole: “When it's all over, it's not who you were . . . it's whether you made a difference.”
Nelson Rockefeller: “America is not just a power,it is a promise. It is not enough for our country to be extraordinary in might; it must be exemplary in meaning.”

Three Republicans who put the country ahead of special interests.

Now, the whole crew wants to transfer whole sectors of public dollars to private, for profit companies. And they are leaping forward at NASCAR pace. Media coverage inches along story by story, but the transfer clearly has all the signs of coordinated strategy by Republican legislatures that slip a pile of bills through without much public notice and then exploit the public treasury with returning any real or lasting public value. The Republicans have found government is a profitable business with a steady stream of line item expenses that can be created and authorized to be turned over to open and waiting private hands.

Of course, their budgets don’t add up, their logic leads to dead ends, their ideas of progress put the country in reverse. The unsanitized, the field version of the Republican problem has an appeal because the country seeks easy formulas of convenience. So the Republicans present a parade of fallacies as entertaining as the floats in a holiday parade.

Republicans promise the gift of freedom from the responsibility of managing public affairs while they rapidly expand government to intrude into every aspect of individual life throught fiats of control rather than regulation. The budget and governing is only important for expanding private wealth, removing the obstacles and safeguards to emptying the public treasury into corporate hands, by manadates with no oversight. Through the budget, they seek to bypass legislative deliberation and use the purse strings to exercise executive authority. It’s not just education; its banks, health, job creation, the environment, overseas investments, wages, and innovation, they are setting up the whole country to fail. More record profits this quarter, bigger executive bonuses, but where are the middle class jobs? Where are the quality teachers who will instill the life long joy of learning and meeting new challenges? A system built on alt-cert can not share best practices or create trained professionals; it's simply a license to grow the educational deficit at public expense.

Their short term false promises have important, long term consequences.
--Walter Rhett

I always get a kick out of the computer-generated ads appearing alongside op-eds and news stories in The Times. The ads are based on the subject matter of each piece and its keywords, and are usually unintentionally hilarious.

For example, alongside this Gail Collins column lambasting abysmal teacher training-for-profit were ads for similar on-line universities where you can buy teaching credentials on the cheap -- and all behind the anonymous screen of your own cheap home computer. Of course, these classes will only attract the best and the brightest G.E.D. grads and probably a few rejects from Catholic seminaries and aspiring Boy Scout leaders. (For some reason, there was also an ad for a school purporting to help you get an "intelligence degree" if your career goal involves the CIA).

The deliberate dumbing down of America seems to be official Republican party policy, and the latest statistics indicate we don't have far to go before hitting rock bottom. According to recent tests administered by the Department of Education, more than half of eighth graders do not know the purpose of the Bill of Rights. Three-quarters of high school seniors could not name one power granted to Congress by the Constitution. Only 10 percent of the middle schoolers demonstrated knowledge of the checks and balances among the three branches of government.

But that is probably all according to Republican plan, which defines checks as those pieces of paper with dollar signs endorsable by them, and balances meaning Fair and Balanced Fox News coverage. An educated electorate is a clear and present danger to those who stay in power through sheer mendacity and whose concern for children is limited solely to the nine months they stay in the womb.

The biggest problem with American education is all the legislators and so-called educators who were educated -- or not -- in America. When you have know-nothings in state legislatures and on school boards across the nation deciding the curricula, why be surprised when the kids come out knowing nothing? In Texas, members of the state school board want the kids to learn that Newt Gingrich and Phyllis Schlafly were great Americans, and Martin Luther King, Jr. was kind of a Black Panther who had the same goals as Alabama's segregationist Governor George Wallace. Sounds about right to me. And maybe this kind of "education" will be a big help to Newt, who we learned yesterday is running for president in a surprise video announcement he made that reminded me a lot of Christine O'Donnell's "I An Not a Witch" ad. Although he did not wear pearls.

Meanwhile, Republican complaints about "elite" teachers who have cushy part-time jobs with summers off to loll around and do nothing are not helping, nor are Republican efforts -- a number of them successful -- to cripple teachers' unions. Probably the unionized teachers are among the rabble-rousers who think classroom internships are an essential element of teacher training.

The move to for-profit education is appalling. One of the biggest proponents of for-profit education is Florida's former Governor Jeb Bush who runs a "foundation" which is largely funded, coincidentally I'm sure, by the very for-profit schools Jeb runs around the country promoting. In fact, the reason Jeb has given for not running for President is that he "wants to make some money for his family." I guess promoting for-profit education is pretty lucrative. The President of the United States has a crummy salary of $400,000 a year, plus a $50,000 expense account. And when he quits his job, he and his wife can make millions in book deals and speaking engagements. That is so not enough for Jeb and his family.

I'm thinking if we are ever going to "Win the Future," we had better import some of those experts from Finland, Australia and Japan who are running programs geared to teaching kids useful skills and accurate information, and to treating their teachers with dignity and fair compensation. We've had quite enough of American "experts'" input. In the last couple of decades these geniuses have moved American education from the best in the world to about 15th place. Thanks, but no thanks, Jeb. Same to you, Arne Duncan.

Unfortunately, Texas and Ohio are far from the only states where conservatives are trying to undermine public education.

For example, in Idaho, the state legislature is considering a bill that would eliminate 770 teaching positions, increase class sizes, and try to move students to on-line classes by giving them a laptop. Not surprisingly, major donors to the Republicans who support this legislation are companies that run on-line education programs. Other legislation pending in Idaho would weaken collective bargaining rights of teachers and begin to implement “performance-based” pay policies.

In Pennsylvania, Indiana, and 33 other states, reactionary Republican Governors and/or state legislators are pushing for school voucher programs that would allow a small number of students attend private schools on the taxpayer's dime. Many of these Republicans are combining such proposals with attempts to massively cut funding for public education.

And at the national level, Republicans are seeking to restore a voucher program in DC while, unfortunately, the Obama Administration is pushing for expansions of charter schools.

The problem with all of this is that it is doing very little to actually help education our children. Study after study have shown that charter schools perform no better than public schools. While charter schools are a bit cheaper on a per student basis, that is largely because they have much lower proportions of ESL students, disabled students, and other students who have additional needs. Vouchers, at best, allow only a few students, most of whom are relatively well-off, to attend private schools while taking away resources from public schools.

The simple fact is that the best way to improve education in America is to improve public education, as 90% of students attend public schools and other options have done no better despite strong support from politicians and rich philanthropists. Instead of diverting our resources, let's increase funding for schools, reduce class size, pay teachers better, provide additional tutoring, and take the other steps needed to give all of our children a fair start.

Let 'em eat cake.

That's the sentiment. At some point in the near future, when the forces of corporatism have their way, education will be a strictly private matter. The provision of educational services will be left to market forces, meaning, of course, that some will simply not be able to afford it, and those who can will be sending their money to private corporations to educate their kids. Charter schools, vouchers, the dismantling of student loan programs, are all meant to not only wrest control of the educational system from the public, but to eliminate public education altogether, in much the same way the drive to privatize Social Security is meant to spell its ultimate demise.

Why pay into Social Security when we can privatize it and private investment firms can make billions? Why pay for Medicare when Paul Ryan can simply turn over the tax dollars to private insurance companies? Why use the power of government to provide universal el-hi education or to promote higher education when we can privatize it and create private profit? Who cares if poor kids don't get educated? They weren't going anywhere anyway.
